courtesy of Lord of War movie....but anyways I thought about that quote for a while and wondered how true it was. Could it be just that? I find it hard to believe.....evil has always been there....and can't always be suppressed by good people. I don't know...just something to chew on....

post_info.post_title: "Evil Prevails when Good Men Fail To Act"....

Actually it's generally attributed to Edmund Burke: "The only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothing."
 
 Is it true? Near enough, I think. Evil, after all, isn't just an abstract entity floating about. It's people doing bad things. If a person isn't willing, for whatever reason, to stop themselves from being evil, then someone else will have to do it. And since many acts that we consider evil consist of taking things from others (property, liberty, life) it's quite reasonable to assume that an evil person could acquire power and "triumph" if not opposed.

Burke believed that people had become insensitive to vice (or "evil") and as a sensitising agent he recommended "wise prejudice" which, he said, is an ally of reason because it complements and gives effect to rational judgments.

And that's just one example of evil being stopped by good.

Evil occurs not only when good men fail to act, but far more often, when good men act in misguided ways.
 
 It is not enough to know that you are good and to act, Bush believes he is good, and he certainly has acted. But this action has not prevented evil, it has encouraged it.

Evil occurs not only when good men fail to act, but far more often, when good men act in misguided ways.
 
 It is not enough to know that you are good and to act, Bush believes he is good, and he certainly has acted. But this action has not prevented evil, it has encouraged it.

 So would you agree that the issue is not cut and dried?

I'm not sure that it is necessary to be a "good person" in order to act with wisdom and good judgment. The failures of Mr Bush's policy (which are more obvious with hindsight) do not, in my opinion, proceed from his moral character but from his lack of political sagacity. 
 
 On the decision to "liberate" Iraq, he listened to bad advice and untrustworthy intelligence - though he is culpable for appointing the people who gave it. 
 
 James.
I tell you what scares me more then evil is when "good" men act against it especially if I happen to be smoking some of it at the time.

The real problem is that Good and Evil are subjective terms, eg. "killing people is bad - ergo; evil" but sending the soldiers off to kill people suddenly becomes "good", (Especially when the bloke who sent them off is sitting in comfortable office on another continent).
 Who represents the so-called "Good guys" and "Bad guys" will depend on who you ask, very few leaders have claimed to be "Evil", the only one I can think of is Edward Teach, and I suspect he did it more to terrify his victims than in any serious sence.
 History is written by the victors, had Germany won in the '40s I suspect the "good guys" would still be on top.
Who prevails when evil fights evil to a stalemate? Good! And Good doesn't need to do anything.
Or evil fights evil to the point where they nuke each other but that will not be a victory for good just a big mess.

Like I implied one mans meat is another mans poison.
 Is AA evil? I don't believe in the concept of evil myself. In the specific case of AA, he's undeniably beligerant, aggressive and provocative. Classic Alpha type personality which leads him to take a domineering position if you let him. That certainly rubs people up the wrong way. Of course understanding his personality type allows us a degree of manipulation. The Alpha type is driven by his ego and by concentrating on that you can get him to do what you want.
 Whilst superficially similar to EZ his underlying traits show him to be less malevolent, even having a degree of insecurity.
 Back on topic;
 I've already discussed the ambiguity of killing people, going onto other things is alcohol evil? The temperance movement tried to have alcohol banned, In the US they temporarily succeeded leading to growth in organised crime and murders. In Britain they thought they could replace alcohol with chocolate giving us Cadbury's and Rowntree, this attitude towards the product explains the difference with the European chocolate which was produced for it's own sake rather than mass production to stamp out something else.
 By attempting to tackle something they saw as evil did the temperance movement do more harm than good?
 We can make the same observations with trades unions which seem to have stiffled the competitiveness of European countries leading to mass unemployment.

 With AA the operative components of the exchange were;
 
 And don't you dare tell me I don't understand evolution 

 which I then repeated to prime him, and challenged using as much of the original wording as possible;
 
You don't understand evolution.

 the rest of the post was essentially camoflage for the trap.

 http://www.psych.uncc.edu/pagoolka/TypeA-B-intro.html
 OK the link is to the Jenkins Activity test which assesses you on the Alpha-Beta personality scale the results are out of 380, I score 159 which puts me towards the Beta end.
 In Biology Alpha and Beta traits have to do with breeding strategies, the theory being that dominant males will mate with more females, have more offspring in the next generation leading to more dominant behaviour and increased chance of mating and so on and so forth. The evolutionary legacy of this is that we see aggressive dominant behaviour in males in many animal species so AA is simply expressing his genetic bias in the same way as any baboon. If he detects a challenge he will see this as a threat to his abilities to impress the females with his fitness and respond accordingly. Of course this is at a near subconcious, instinctive level. He doesn't actually go through that thought process, its more "Attack now, think later". Conciously of course I'm not a threat his breeding rights with any females and I doubt any of the females here will be swooning at his display of "Vigour and virility", though we can ask them if we're curious.
 Whether we would see each other as competitors for mates is difficult to tell, seeing as we have... different tastes.
 If you were to think of an incident where your emotions got the better of you, could you identify the emotional trigger that set you off?
 
 On Zardoz point, An Omega type personality would have been hideously unlikely to make the initial "Don't you dare" comment, that would go against the grain.
 Whilst a Beta type may have made the initial comment they wouldn't respond to the challenge in the manner that AA did. The responce would have been to the paragraph after the challenge and been much more measured.
 He might have felt affronted but you wouldn't have seen the rage like that. A smilie would have been likely the major sign, perhaps some huffy language. But what he posted was stream of conciousness, him in an unadulterated format.

That would put you towards the Beta end; someone who is more creative and philosophical than objective orientated. A team player rather than the more self centred Alpha type.

Is there any evidence that alpha/beta are actual personality types and not just stereotypes, things that sound right when you read them because they carry a bit of truth for everyone, like a horoscope?
 
 I mean I like the Myer-Briggs personality inventories, but even they seem to have scant evidence behind them, the OCEAN inventory is probably the most well regarded but even it has some questions lingering.
 
 I've never even heard of the alpha/beta being like a real distinction? Is it necessarily a general factor or could it be domain specific, could someone act like an alpha in counterstrike but a beta at work, for example?

In Biology it's quite well defined, Psychology on the other hand seems to be slightly different. In the 40's - 50's they noticed a correlation with heart disease and Alpha type, further study shows that those who have the Alpha type are more likely to indulge in the lifestyle which results in heart disease rather than Alpha type being the direct cause.
 I think the current thinking is in Psychology focuses on the "Big Five" traits. 
 Then again I suspect the field is prone to "Pet Theories".

considering that this is a thread on the quote "Evil prevails when good men fail to act." I'm going to treat it as such an ignore the off topic posts, and conntribute my oppinion on this quote. I belive that a different saying would fit this world. That would be Evil prevails when good men fail in their acts. I say this because through out history there have been evil people (and throwing aside different belifes, I think we can all agree that there have been evil people in the past) and in order for those evil people to get into history very certian aspects were met for them to gain power. Good men try to end evil every day however an equal number or more try to premote it.

Are there any good men? Or women?
 
 Or, must we pray for the odd chance that an evil person will inadvertently do good?

And that's just one example of evil being stopped by good.

 Who represents the so-called "Good guys" and "Bad guys" will depend on who you ask, very few leaders have claimed to be "Evil", the only one I can think of is Edward Teach, and I suspect he did it more to terrify his victims than in any serious sence.
 History is written by the victors, had Germany won in the '40s I suspect the "good guys" would still be on top.
